awd_titl_txt: Expanding the Capabilities of SERS via Electronic Raman Spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) Program in the Division of Chemistry, Matthew Sheldon and his group at Texas A&M University are learning how to use a specific type of molecular sensor to obtain new information about the changes in chemical systems when they interact with light at a metal surface; namely, surface enhanced Raman scattering (SERS). This information is important for understanding how light from the sun can be converted into other forms of energy, such as chemical fuels. The molecular sensors are based on metal surfaces that are precisely structured at the nanometer scale. The reflection of light by these metal surfaces is strongly modified when molecules are on the sensor surface in a way that provides unique, identifying information about the molecules. The research team is examining a background signal caused by the reflection of light from the surface. This background signal is often ignored, but may provide new information about the transfer of energy into or out of molecules at the surface when irradiated with light, as well as additional information about the identity of the molecules. The project will provide support for graduate and undergraduate research students working in the Sheldon laboratory, and the team will work to recruit first-generation college students from underrepresented groups starting in their freshman year.

In this work, Matthew T. Sheldon and his group are developing spectroscopic techniques to understand the photochemical behavior of metal substrates that are used for molecular sensing via surface enhanced Raman scattering (SERS). SERS spectroscopy typically measures the vibrational spectrum of a molecule, but the electronic Raman (eR) response of the metal SERS substrate also gives a strong “background” signal that has traditionally been ignored. The eR signal is characteristic of the energy distribution of electrons in the metal and can provide additional, unique chemical insights compared with the molecular SERS signal. This research by the Sheldon group examines how the eR signal can give detailed spectroscopic insights into the dynamics of electron excitation and charge transfer, even when there may be limited or ambiguous molecular signals (e.g. no Raman-active species). The experiments will provide a foundation for SERS methodologies that can provide quantitative insight into photochemistry and photocatalysis during low fluence, continuous wave (CW) illumination that is similar to the conditions that are relevant for solar energy conversion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Surface-enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (SERS) is a powerful analytical technique widely used in chemistry to detect extremely low concentrations of chemicals. Despite its usefulness, several major limitations have historically impeded its broader application, particularly the difficulty in precisely quantifying how much the signal is enhanced by the substrate and the presence of unwanted background signals from the substrates themselves. Additionally, the intense light used in SERS can sometimes alter the chemical properties of the substances being analyzed, complicating accurate analysis.

To address these challenges, this project developed innovative experimental techniques centered around electronic Raman (eR) spectroscopy. Unlike traditional Raman spectroscopy, which examines molecular vibrations, eR spectroscopy focuses on the electrons in the metallic nanostructures that form the SERS substrates. By developing a deeper understanding of these electronic signals, the project significantly advanced our ability to analyze and optimize the performance of SERS substrates.

One of our major accomplishments was clarifying how "hot electrons," which are highly energetic electrons excited by light in metal nanostructures, behave under continuous illumination. We identified critical differences in hot electron lifetimes and energy distributions depending on the type of excitation used, significantly impacting potential applications in photocatalysis and energy harvesting technologies. Additionally, our research revealed novel ways to control these electrons and their properties using the polarization state of light, providing a powerful tool for researchers developing new sensors and energy conversion technologies.

A notable discovery made during this project involved "subradiant plasmonic cavities," special nanoscale structures that can significantly alter how molecules interact with light. Our research demonstrated that these cavities could convert normally visible molecular signals (polaritons) into invisible, or "dark," states. This finding opened new avenues for chemical analysis at the nanoscale, particularly enabling new methods for nanoscale imaging and chemical analysis that could have substantial implications for biological sensing, medical diagnostics, and environmental monitoring.

Beyond scientific discoveries, this project had a substantial impact on training the next generation of scientists and engineers. Three graduate students and one undergraduate student received extensive research training through active participation in the project each year. Graduate students gained valuable experience mentoring undergraduates, further developing their leadership skills. All students involved presented their findings at prominent scientific conferences, including the Gordon Research Conferences and other national meetings, enhancing their communication skills, professional development, and career opportunities.

Finally, the outcomes of this research were broadly disseminated through high-impact scientific journals and international conferences, reaching researchers worldwide across multiple scientific disciplines. Publications resulting from this project appeared in top scientific journals such as ACS Nano, Nanophotonics, Annual Review of Physical Chemistry, Nature Photonics, and Nano Letters. By sharing these insights, the project has influenced a wide range of fields, from analytical chemistry and photochemistry to energy science and materials engineering, demonstrating significant intellectual merit and broader impacts of this work.
